pros: Some positive influence on an extremely trying time for a family. Most people there care about there clients.
cons: Crisis services has a lot of potential but the system needs to be reworked. The turnover rate isn't high due to the nature of the work, it's due to the set up of the system. Asking for real feed back from your employees instead of just from upper management who aren't actually involved on a daily basis is the only way to fix it.

review_title: Poor pay, poor hours if full time, more drama than high school. The actual work is easy, the drama is the hard part.
pros:
Has PTO if full time
If PRN, somewhat flexible schedule (if there are shifts to take)
The actual work isn't usually very difficult, normally you just stand around with a clipboard, occasionally it gets difficult when there are any hostile clients on the unit.
Very rewarding if you like to help people
cons: You must be able to handle clients in crisis. This can be very emotionally difficult for some people. However, in my opinion the most difficult part of working here is the drama from other coworkers. It is a VERY unprofessional environment, and everybody has something to say about someone. If you're full time, there's always mandatory overtime. If you work full time weekends, you work 7a to 11p Saturday and Sunday and then you're REQUIRED to work 11p to 8a on a weekday to make up for the 9 hours you didn't work over the weekend(You aren't paid for an hour's worth of lunch). On top of that, the benefits are horrible and not really worth paying into, there are no raises, and the pay is very meager. The supervisors only make a dollar more an hour than the techs. The entire place is funded mostly by the state, so it has very tight purse strings. You can tell that by walking on the unit...the whole place is very drab, and is reminiscent of a prison. The paint is peeling, the plumbing system is ancient and always floods, the floor constantly looks like it needs to be mopped, the meals that clients get are at best the size of a snack, the group leaders require NO formal training or experience to lead groups and oftentimes know very little about actual mental health.....and the list goes on.

review_title: Could be such a great program...
pros: I enjoy the clients, PTO time earned is a plus
cons: Lack of mutual respect among staff, the manager will walk right by you and not acknowledge you, I don't think gathering the clients in a room and call it group time to put a movie in or turn on the TV is therapeutic . Staff and clients are not nurtured at all,

review_title: Overall, the company provides excellent services for the community.
pros: They provide excellent care and provide referral services to clients that may not meet their eligibility requirements.
cons: Some employees are not happy with their jobs and will make another employee feel that way...need more employee satisfaction.

pros: Opportunities for growth if you stay with the company long term
cons: Constant changes to work requirements and caseload. Be prepared to work way beyond the 9-5 hours, management often discuss accommodating client's schedule to make the most billable hours possible. Heavy on documentation.

review_title: I provide security and maintain peace on the stabilization unit.
job_title: Psychiatric Security Specialist in Bartow, FL
pros:
Flexible schedule 
Good bosses
Good location
cons:
Pts can try to fight you
Under staffed
Poor pay

pros: Comfortable, convenient, and it sounds good
cons: Low pay, benefits are a joke, very little room to grow

pros:
Getting to work with different clients
Teaching Group
Co-Workers
